results.title: Professor Erikson. Part 1
results.creator_credit: James L. Brown and KUHT Film Productions
results.brief_description: An investigation of some theories of psychoanalysis, and personality growth. The film takes the form of an interview between Dr Erik Erikson, of Harvard University, a pioneer in the field of child analysis and research and Dr Richard Evans, of the University of Houston. They discuss Erikson’s theory of the eight stages of psycho development. Part 1 and 2 produced under a grant awarded by the national Science Foundation, USA.

results.title: Problems to be solved
results.brief_description: A restrained dramatic presentation of the problems of personal relationships and private worries in the office. A cleaner find mute evidence of the past day’s tensions as she moves around each desk. The office boy feels he is learning nothing; a clerk is extremely tense; a young mother worried about the child who must be left alone in the house; an executive is continually short-tempered and panicky; the manger has too full a timetable to do more than notice the existence of these problems.

results.title: Prism of purpose
results.brief_description: Gabo Island - Artist Alexandra Lyall’s paintings of the Gabo Island lighthouse provide haunting visuals to her moving account of the role the lighthouse played in a tragic family history.This work uses digital technology cleverly to allow you to experience Alexandra’s paintings in a new way.

results.title: Principles of routine composition
results.creator_credit: Mary Ann Reeves and Coaching Association of Canada
results.brief_description: Step by step instruction on how to compose a routine for synchronised swimming. Counting out music, land drills, coaching techniques, putting ideas together and practical methods are all considered.

results.title: Primary adventure
results.brief_description: Made as part of the Inner London Education Authority’s contribution to the commemoration of the centenary of the Forster Education Act of 1870. The film shows modern methods of teaching and learning in primary schools during 1970.
